#Text=Prune Forsythia
#Text=Forsythias are large bushes with bright yellow flowers that bloom in the early springtime .
#Text=When pruning , aim to give each stem lots of room as it grows .
#Text=If you want your plant to grow as many flowers as possible , prune it in the springtime after it blooms .
#Text=If you want to tame an overgrown plant , prune it in the summer , fall , or winter .
#Text=Prune your forsythias once a year so your plants stay healthy and look great !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Pruning at the Right Time
#Text=Prune forsythia plants right after they finish blooming in the spring .
#Text=Wait for your yellow flowers to fade and for the leaves to grow .
#Text=At this point , the plant starts to develop next year 's buds , and the plant carries the buds through the fall and winter season .
#Text=This is the best time to prune your forsythia .
#Text=Prune in the summer , fall , or winter to reduce the number of flowers .
#Text=If you wait to prune your forsythias until after the springtime , the number of flowers that your plant yields next season will be considerably less .
#Text=This is a good idea if your bush is large and unruly and you want to tame it back .
#Text=You may sacrifice a season of flowers , but your forsythia bush will look much better the next year .
#Text=Avoid pruning your forsythia when the plant is 1-3 years old .
#Text=Young forsythias need little to no pruning .
#Text=Only when they mature should you prune them once a year .
#Text=If you want to help maintain the shape of the plant as it grows , you can snip off a few longer stems once a year , though this is not required .
#Text=Letting the plant take its natural shape helps it establish a healthy root system .
#Text=Pruning Mature Forsythias
#Text=Remove a quarter of the oldest stems by cutting them at ground level .
#Text=The stems get thicker as they age , and they start to rub against each other towards the inside of the shrub .
#Text=This can cause disease and infection .
#Text=To prevent this , use a handsaw to remove some of your old , thick stems .
#Text=Move your handsaw back and forth quickly to make your cuts .
#Text=The largest stems have the thickest diameter .
#Text=The oldest stems typically are also the tallest .
#Text=By getting rid of them , you reduce the overall height of your shrub .
#Text=If you ca n’t reach the very middle of the shrub ’s base , cut it to from the ground .
#Text=Do this after your plants mature to about 5-6 years old .
#Text=This way , they are large enough to support such a massive pruning .
#Text=Cut the stems to or more if you want to encourage growth .
#Text=Use a pair of loppers or a fine-tooth handsaw to cut your large stems .
#Text=Instead of cutting them at the ground , leave about of the stem .
#Text=This way , new stems can grow from the remaining portion of the branch .
#Text=Trimming the top of the stem off helps reduce the height of your plant while promoting a spot for new shoots to grow .
#Text=Remove branches low to the ground to maintain the shape of the plant .
#Text=Sometimes , the forsythia plant grows branches toward the base .
#Text=This does not look the best , since most of the flowers bloom at the canopy of the plant .
#Text=To reshape your plant , simply cut off these branches using your pruning shears .
#Text=Make your cut where the branch first sprouts off the other stem .
#Text=If you do n’t remove low branches , they may start to root to the ground .
#Text=Get rid of any dead , bent , or split stems to keep your plant healthy .
#Text=As perennials grow , they often produce a few dead branches .
#Text=In addition , the dense stems may start to touch or rub together .
#Text=If you previously trimmed a stem , new “ split stems ” may grow where the cut was made .
#Text=While these instances occur normally as the plant grows , they can take away nutrients and expose the plant to infection .
#Text=If you notice any stems growing inward rather than outward , these should be pruned as well .
#Text=Dead , bent , and split stems also change the look of your shrub .
#Text=Cut branches back to their point of origin to thin out the canopy .
#Text=Use pruning shears or loppers to remove any excess branches towards the top of your plant .
#Text=This helps preserve the natural shape of your forsythia while getting rid of the bulk .
#Text=Do this for branches that point inward , branches that cross , and branches that are rubbing against other branches .
#Text=In addition , cut off some of the very tall branches .
#Text=Removing branches displays the natural shape of the plant .
#Text=Keeping your forsythia open allows light and air into the middle of the shrub , which helps it grow healthy .
#Text=Crop the stems to if they are drastically overgrown .
#Text=Only do this if your plant is an overgrown mess and starts to take over your garden bed .
#Text=Using loppers , cut all of your stems to the ground .
#Text=Make your cuts about from the ground so new shoots can start to grow .
#Text=After this , remove excess branches to keep your plant open and airy .
#Text=For best results , do this in late winter or early spring .
#Text=Blooming will be reduced or nonexistent after a dramatic pruning .
#Text=After a few years , your plant will look full again .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Pruning shears
#Text=Loppers
#Text=Handsaw
#Text=Warnings
#Text=If left unpruned , forsythia plants can get very large and take over other areas of your garden .
#Text=Avoid cutting off the top of your forsythia with hedge clippers .
#Text=While this may get rid of the bulk of your shrub faster , the plant will grow excessive , dense growth where you make your cuts .
#Text=Avoid trimming your forsythia into a hedge .
#Text=This results in more branches to clip off and less flowers overall .
#Text=If you want your forsythia to look its best , let it grow outward rather than shaping it into a hedge .
#Text=Hedge-shaped forsythias require pruning several times a year rather than just 1 time in the spring .
